instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had no 20v, only 5v from the charger and that was cycling.
No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> but no short on that line.
Found short to ground on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
Removed <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, now short on 3105 is gone and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is normal but still no 20v on any of the ports.
I am not familiar with how this board behaves and I do not have another donor board to check with.
Will any of the other ports get 20v with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> removed?
I have several <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> on the way.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message:
You must change the chip, not just remove.
Be aware to use the same code termination.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message: Yeah have to replace the chip with another all 4 must be installed. Has to be same firmware

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply.
What exactly do you mean by code termination? The last few digits after the part number?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message: Has anyone been successful in rewriting the firmware on these?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question, short on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>
threads.message:
Please write new post instead of comment.

No way to reprogram these chips.
You must use the same code; CD3215B03 will not work in place of CD3215C00, for example (nor viceversa).
